question: Which celestial object in the solar system is closest to Earth?

content.source_1: The Moon orbits Earth at a mean distance of about 384,400 km, ranging roughly between 356,500 km (perigee) and 406,700 km (apogee).
content.source_2: Even at their closest approaches, the nearest planets remain much farther: Venus approaches to about 38–41 million km and Mercury to about 77 million km from Earth.
content.source_3: Ephemeris-based, time-specific solar-system plots (used by observatories and planetarium software) place all tracked bodies—planets, the Moon, and cataloged minor planets—at their actual positions for a given date.
content.source_4: On 2020-11-13, near-Earth asteroid 2020 VT4 passed about 400 km above Earth’s surface, far inside the Moon’s orbit.
content.source_5: On 2020-08-16, near-Earth asteroid 2020 QG flew by within about 2,950 km of Earth, also well inside the Moon’s orbit.
content.source_6: At any moment, the Moon is still hundreds of thousands of kilometers away, so during such flybys the passing asteroid is the nearest distinct object to Earth.
